abstract: The Knick, Steven Soderberghs Cinemax series about early-20th-century medicine, is striving for historical accuracy, no matter how gruesome.
author: By JENNIFER SCHUESSLER
title: The Cocaine, the Blood, the Body Count

abstract: Atheist TV, now available online and through the streaming service Roku, defines itself by what it wont be.
author: By NEIL GENZLINGER
title: Believe It Or Not, Atheists, TV for You

abstract: The Hawaii-born actor, who first found fame in Japan, helped break Hollywood clichs about Asian-American performers.
author: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
title: James Shigeta, 85, Leading Man in Flower Drum Song, Dies

abstract: David Shafers first book, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot, is about a multinational cabal that plans to subjugate humanity by privatizing all information.
author: By DWIGHT GARNER
title: Maybe Theres a Whole Other Internet

abstract: How the bands deconstructed songs deliver the power of familiarity without sounding anything like the rock music you know.
author: By DAN KOIS
copyright: Graeme Mitchell for The New York Times
title: Spoon, the Molecular Gastronomists of Rock

abstract: The Invisible Bridge, Rick Perlsteins panoramic third volume about the rise of the modern conservative movement in America, covers the span of 1973 to 1976.
author: By FRANK RICH
title: A Distant Mirror

abstract: A House Natural Resources Committee report criticized the commission behind a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower over spending and its choice of a designer.
author: By ROBIN POGREBIN
title: Memorial Plan Called a Five-Star Folly

abstract: In Sharknado 2: The Second One, Syfy moves its meteorological phenomenon of flying man-eaters from Los Angeles to New York.
author: By NEIL GENZLINGER
title: Jaws Open, Monster Storm Hits East Coast

abstract: Calvary, John Michael McDonaghs mordantly funny murder mystery, revolves around an Irish Roman Catholic priest.
author: By MANOHLA DARGIS
title: Forgive Me, Father, for I Must Sin

abstract: Cate Blanchett and Isabelle Huppert reflect on their taxing roles as homicidal sisters in Genets 1947 play The Maids, opening at the Lincoln Center Festival.
author: By ALEXIS SOLOSKI
title: Sadistic Fantasy in a Fun House Mirror

abstract: I had two sources of warmth during the cold middle-school years: a cocoon of books and a bowl of shelf-stable noodles.
author: By VERONIQUE GREENWOOD
title: How Ramen Got Me Through Adolescence

abstract: James Cameron documents his expedition to the Mariana Trench, the deepest part of the ocean, in the documentary Deepsea Challenge 3D.
author: By MEKADO MURPHY
title: Taking Selfies, 35,000 Feet Down

abstract: This biography of Beethoven is also a personal journey through his music and the Enlightenment-era ferment that shaped it.
author: By JEREMY DENK
title: Immortal Beloved

abstract: Ask conductors and musicians, and theyll single out the Vienna Philharmonic for its unique style, one that has persisted as other orchestras sound more alike. Whats its secret?
author: By MICHAEL COOPER
title: A Sound Shaped by Time and Tools

abstract: Visitors from all over are lining up at the Louvre, the Vatican and the Uffizi museums, posing problems for institutions trying to balance accessibility with art preservation.
author: By RACHEL DONADIO
copyright: Guia Besana for The New York Times
title: Masterworks vs. the Masses

abstract: Ram V. Sutar, one of the worlds most prolific sculptors, braces for the possibility of his most gigantic commission yet.
author: By GARDINER HARRIS
copyright: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
title: An Indian Sculptor With Monumental Ambition

abstract: Cambridge University has digitized 4,100 handwritten pages of notes by the British wartime poet Siegfried Sassoon and has made them available free online.
author: By ALAN COWELL
title: A Soldier Poet, Baring His Soul

abstract: The strange little documentary Nixon by Nixon: In His Own Words, which airs Monday on HBO, alternates a public persona with a closeted monster revealed by secret White House tapes.
author: By MIKE HALE

abstract: A comic book property like “Guardians of the Galaxy” may seem ideal for the big screen, but comics have singular pleasures of their own.

abstract: Thomas Mallon and Pankaj Mishra discuss whether there is any use in retaining old labels of cultural prestige.
author: By THOMAS MALLON and PANKAJ MISHRA
title: Highbrow, Lowbrow, Middlebrow  Do These Kinds of Cultural Categories Mean Anything Anymore?

abstract: The author, most recently, of Lucky Us would like to invite Sappho, George Bernard Shaw and James Baldwin over for a literary dinner. Its not clear to me that everyone will get along.
title: Amy Bloom: By the Book

abstract: Hours after a mediator began work Thursday evening, the Metropolitan Opera granted a temporary deadline extension.
author: By MICHAEL COOPER
title: In Final Hours, Metropolitan Opera Extends Contract Deadlines for Unions

abstract: Peter Mendelsund has designed hundreds of striking book covers, but his imagination seized up when it came time to design one for his own book.
author: By ALEXANDRA ALTER
copyright: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
title: The Creative Art of Selling a Book by Its Cover

abstract: A theater critic imagines a clash of the greatest versions of Shakespeares melancholy prince, as portrayed by John Barrymore, Laurence Olivier, Richard Burton and others.

abstract: Money for silence; money in hiding.
author: By CHUCK KLOSTERMAN

abstract: Emily K. Rafferty, the first woman to serve as president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, announced that she would step down in the spring of 2015.

abstract: The same thing as Rick Perry, Scott Walker and Bobby Jindal: Talking about how much he loves Iowa!

abstract: Meditations on exposing an innocent adorable creature to this brutal, perverse world.

abstract: Kelsey Grammer and Martin Lawrence play lawyers in the new FX sitcom Partners.

abstract: There are historic examples that point to reasons for worry in the current contract dispute between 15 unions and the Met.

abstract: War Story centers on an overseas American photographer with a damaged psyche.

abstract: Science fiction, fantasy, history and romance blend in the new Starz series Outlander.

abstract: Mr. Farockis subject matter as an artist and filmmaker was the unexamined absurdities of the corporate and military world.

abstract: What We See When We Read, by the graphic artist Peter Mendelsund, explores the way we graft our own images onto the people and places we encounter in fiction.

abstract: New books by Edan Lepucki, Scott Cheshire, Bill Morris, Mark Chiusano, Alberto Moravia and Can Xue visit California, Detroit and Marine Park in Brooklyn, among other places.

abstract: In Yannick Murphys thriller This Is the Water, the mother of two girls on a competitive swim team is having an affair with her friends husband.

author: By BINYAMIN APPELBAUM

abstract: Mr. Smiths handiwork could be seen in the Godfather films as well as Amadeus, The Exorcist and more, using plaster masks and liquid foam latex.

abstract: An exiled magician tries a risky heist in Lev Grossmans novel, the final installment of a trilogy.

abstract: A refrigeration boom is changing the way Chinese people eat  and threatening the planet in the process.

abstract: Between Riverside and Crazy, a new play by Stephen Adly Guirgis, centers on a retired policeman threatened with eviction and his extended family and friends.

abstract: David Eimer aims to give Chinas ethnic minorities a voice in his timely new book.

abstract: Nigel Hamilton argues that Roosevelts genius for military leadership has been underrated and overshadowed.

abstract: The strikingly graphic correspondence from Harding, perhaps the worst chief executive in U.S. history, to his longtime mistress.

abstract: At the Vail International Dance Festival in Colorado, dancers are paired with colleagues from other companies and dare to try new material.

abstract: The film director John Michael McDonagh, older brother of the playwright Martin, has become a filmmaker to watch in his own right with “The Guard” and now “Calvary.”

abstract: Joe Swanbergs modest Happy Christmas is a serious comedy about marriage, parenthood and creative life.

abstract: New books by Jordan Ellenberg, David J. Hand, Michael Blastland and David Spiegelhalter, Amir Alexander, and Alex Bellos.

abstract: Benedict Andrewss ferocious new production of Tennessee Williamss A Streetcar Named Desire at the Young Vic stars Gillian Anderson and Ben Foster.

abstract: A plan to reopen the prehistoric site has drawn choruses of dissent from scientists, who say that modern-day visitors put the cave paintings in danger.

abstract: The years best books, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.

abstract: From a Byzantine basilica to a Vermeer, an art critic imagines uniting soul-altering artworks from his travels in a single show.

abstract: Theater under the stars attracts all manner of unbidden, and unforgettable, human, creaturely and meteorological participation.

abstract: John le Carr recalls Philip Seymour Hoffmans intensity in performing the role of a self-destructive German intelligence officer in the film adaptation of his novel A Most Wanted Man.

abstract: Mr. Shafman, who also managed artists, worked with many prominent performers over his long career, helping to stage well-received late-career appearances by Red Skelton at Carnegie Hall.

abstract: The National Cryptologic Museum, which is the National Security Agencys public face, opens up about American cryptography  but only that of the past.

copyright: Matt Roth for The New York Times

abstract: Richard Linklaters tender and profound film, which follows a boy and his family over a dozen years in real time, is a meticulously textured work set to the rhythm of life.

abstract: The indie darling and former child star is back after six years of anguished silence  and she wants to blow your mind.

copyright: Holly Andres for The New York Times

abstract: As studios are having flops in the romantic comedy genre, independent filmmakers are scoring by using new twists.
author: By BROOKS BARNES

abstract: Robert Altman, who died in 2006, recounts his long career as a director via archival interviews in an Epix documentary.
author: By NEIL GENZLINGER

abstract: In The Almost Man, a 30-something guy finds that there are consequences to his lingering adolescence.

abstract: Chris Pratt, best known for playing Andy Dwyer on the NBC sitcom Parks and Recreation, has risen beyond Andydom to leading-men roles.

abstract: Ishmael Butler and Tendai Maraire  who compose the creative center of Shabazz Palaces  are shaking up Seattles diverse, idiosyncratic and growing hip-hop scene.

abstract: The FX series Married stars two actors, Judy Greer and Nat Faxon, who radiate chemistry on screen and off.

copyright: Ryan Enn Hughes for The New York Times
title: The Easy Banter and the Vicious Retorts of Married

abstract: A stenciled wings-and-roses design is being used in New York to help memorialize pedestrians or bicyclists who died in collisions with cars.

abstract: Productions of Genets play The Maids have variously zeroed in on class, gender, race and, now, an obsession with celebrity.

abstract: In 1986, the U.S.-Soviet meeting in Reykjavik seemed anything but a Cold War breakthrough.
